reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Slow start but worth the wait
reviews.reviewText: This book started out really slow for me but I found myself getting really invested in the characters and story. I love a good fantasy quest and this read like a short, light version of an epic fantasy. Pared down character list, no over elaborate battle scenes and an easy to follow set of world-rules. My only complaint is the rather abrupt cliff-hanger ending but hopefully I have a chance to read the next book in the series soon so this is not a huge issue. I look forward to the next book in the series and I am definitely glad that I stuck with it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars The Witcher meets The Golden Compass
reviews.reviewText: This book has everything I love: found family, a diverse BIPOC cast, a range of disability rep, a queer normative world, and flawed and often morally-gray characters. It comes together to create an interesting world and plot that, while not wholly unique, captures and keeps you invested from page one.The start of this book, following a fast paced prologue, is a bit slow as the characters come together and begin their quest. I personally enjoyed it as it set up stakes of the book and introduced us to some side characters that I immediately loved and hope make further appearances in later books. By around the midway point, as the pilgrimage is underway, the story picks up and the plot begins to take shape. The mystery around Inara and her powers and connection to a god kept me guessing and Elogast's unwavering loyalty and love of baking had my whole heart. And while not every character is immediately lovable (looking at you, Skedi), by the end, I was rooting for them all.This is a book that left me wanting more. An excellent opening to what will eventually be a trilogy, and I cannot wait to see where it goes!TW: Violence, Blood, Burning, Sacrifice, Death

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I loved this book!
reviews.reviewText: I’ve heard so many reviews of this book that I almost felt like there was no way I could measure up to them. Yet, I adored Godkiller. This book was so finally crafted, and felt like a clockwork watch where every bit of the plot worked and clicked into place. Even when I could see where it was going, there were surprises, and it was so joyous to see how well everything I’ve been thought out.The characters were also so very lovely. Kissen is so well drawn. Complicated and angry but choosing to care for people fiercely in the face of her trauma. Absolutely a five-star read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Wow. This was absolutely amazing. Everything from the characters to the world building just blew me away. Everything seemed like it was handled with such care.I loved Kissen so much. I loved her no nonsense attitude. Elo was such a tortured soul. His guilt and pain from the past showed in such consistent and subtle ways. Inara, despite what happened to her, showed a strong spirit that kept moving forward. And Skedith grew on me. His personal growth softened me to him.The gods in this story were all so unique. Just amazing.After that cliffhanger, I’m more than ready for Sunbringer.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great fantasy book
reviews.reviewText: What a fantastic debut fantasy book. I found the plot to be captivating, the characters well fleshed out, and the world building done extremely well. This was a fantasy book done right!This was a highly enjoyable page turner. I can’t wait for book 2. Bring on Sunbringer!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I'm glad I waited for this book to go on sale, because it wasn't great.My biggest complaint with Godkiller is its lack of craft and execution. This is a story set in what could've been an interesting fantasy world that is actually quite bland. Gods used to be everywhere, but the young king banned their public worship. Despite this, many people still worship gods and are willing to risk it all to go on pilgrimages.The writing in this book is serviceable. The characters are as well. The dialogue is okay. And that makes it not very enjoyable to read. The twist at the end of the book came out of nowhere; the "untwist" of Inara's parentage, despite stray dialogue making it pretty clear that she's half-god (and even possibly the king's daughter), was strangely saved for a future installment.I feel as if the author tried to make Kissen and Elo "unreliable narrators" in that they keep their emotions and thoughts guarded even in their POV chapters. This doesn't work. Instead of making them mysterious or even preserving future twists, it just made their motivations hard to understand. I don't really know why they did the things they did, and the author didn't let us hear it from them either.My last complaint is a twist we get halfway through the book, where Elo realizes he'd been cursed by the inn owner who arranged the pilgrimage party. We're shown many people with curse marks and explicitly told that they're the work of gods. So how did a human make one? It's implied that a god was working through the inn owner... but we don't ever meet that god. What was their reason for cursing Elo? It contradicted previously established worldbuilding and thus it made for a bad twist.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Filled my Witchery needs
reviews.reviewText: Like some other reviews have noted this book is very much in the way of the Witcher. Which for me is to say "Take the Witcher and swap the magic and monsters for Gods."The character development is well written and the world fleshed out.This review is short because I'm tired. You should go read the book. It's a fast read because you're going to want to sit and finish it in one or two sittings (my poor sleep schedule lol).

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars I really enjoyed this
reviews.reviewText: As a book I found the middle of the story a little slow. They weren’t doing much of anything but traveling for a lot of the time. But this would make SUCH a good movie
Love the characters, the plot and the world building!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: A Debut Novel? A Debut Masterpiece
reviews.reviewText: When I found out that Godkiller was the debut novel of Hannah Kaner I was honestly shocked.The writing is confident, the descriptions are lush, and the characters are well-formed.Then I discovered that Kaner had been working on this novel for over 15 years and things started to make a little bit more sense.Godkiller is very clearly a labour of intense love and passion. This is a world that has clearly been iterated on and thought about over a long period of time, deep care has been taken in the crafting of its lore and the structure of its narrative. It's a success at setting things up for a wider trilogy, but also as a story in its own right.For a debut author these are not always easy things to accomplish. Kaner does it with style.Godkiller follows four main characters, each with their own point of view chapters. At first I thought this was going to be disorienting, thankfully that wasn't to be the case and it gave us good insight into the thoughts and feelings of all the characters we were following, especially when all of them finally link up together in the narrative.The story takes these four characters on journies of self-discovery and growth, and by the end of it all none of them are the same. Beliefs are challenged and changed, fights are fought and won and sometimes they are lost. This all culminates in a heartfelt final stand and a twist that I genuinely didn't see coming.There is romance in this book, which if made the main focus can be a bit of a turnoff for me. But it was woven throughout the narrative of the story incredibly well, unobtrusive and natural. Though do be aware there is some mildly graphic sex stuff toward the end so if you aren't fond of that you may want to skip the segment or the book entirely.Godkiller is a masterstroke of a debut novel. It surprises, it thrills and most importantly it grips you from beginning to end. It's an incredible first step into fiction that was clearly crafted with love and care every step of the way. Kaner has done a great job setting up the rest of this series, now all she has to do is stick the landing.
le résumé est très intéressant, mais je n'ai pas encore lu ce livre.

I was taken aback by the depth of this world and the imagery that Hannah Kaner evoked. This reads not like someone's debut, but like a story that benefited from the years-long experience of a seasoned writer. It was never boring, even when the action slowed down, and the characters were easy to love - or hate, when the situation required it.Kissen is an amazing protagonist, whose motivations and character leap from the page. Her companions compliment her nicely as she navigates the world and her relationship with these companions.The perspective switches are nice, as other characters have equally realistic and engaging stories to tell.I give this a 5 star because, for me, it is re-readable. It is epic storytelling and I can't wait for that elusive sequel. The 5 star rating is more than earned.
The print quality of my book is awful. Looks like the printer ran out of Ink.
